3FEC1B6967E44096B2C552E137F7B9C1.description:
Use data from a randomized experiment to compare two
treatments; use simulations to decide if differences between parameters
are significant. ★

088ACBBAEC1348A88569B626A4365281.description:
Use data from a sample survey to estimate a population
mean or proportion; develop a margin of error using simulation models
for random sampling. ★

15472A38F2554BB19907D179BC93AF58.description:
Recognize the purposes of and differences among sample
surveys, experiments, and observational studies; explain how
randomization relates to each. ★

A1E3C47E24554502BE94DCF9076E2CD4.description:
Make inferences and justify conclusions from sample surveys, experiments, and
observational studies.★

3305A62BA9464C2289132F126D6FD380.description:
Decide if a specified model is consistent with results from a
given data-generating process. For example, using simulation or a model
says a spinning coin falls heads up with probability 0.5. Would a result of
5 tails in a row cause you to question the model? ★

8EBA3341857F4946AF645D635DFCD9B0.description:
Understand statistics as a process for making inferences
about population parameters based on a random sample from that
population. ★

D34C6A224E1C4D2985B2D0F59B39E927.description:
Understand and evaluate random processes underlying statistical
experiments.★

4739D0413B874BFEAAC13B8421D82A79.description:
Use the mean and standard deviation of a data set to fit it to
a normal distribution and to estimate population percentages. Recognize
that there are data sets for which such a procedure is not appropriate.
Use calculators, spreadsheets, and tables to estimate areas under the
normal curve. ★

75B0651B08DD49AD82A94FEC509D55DF.description:
Summarize, represent, and interpret data on a single count or measurement
variable. ★

DCA5B0DA6EF44190B94FBB74810516D2.description:
Choose trigonometric functions to model periodic
phenomena with specified amplitude, frequency, and midline. ★

4129C71FCEBC499BA24F0391CFAB52BE.description: Model periodic phenomena with trigonometric functions.

D9FDDCD8F4ED4A10B6A4AB0C48A4931B.description:
Use the unit circle to explain symmetry (odd and even) and
periodicity of trigonometric functions.

CB6DC7BADF114ADDB9EBA41D898DD5C6.description:
Use special triangles to determine geometrically the values
of sine, cosine for 𝜋𝜋
3
,
𝜋𝜋
4
, and 𝜋𝜋
6
, and use the unit circle to express the
values of sine and cosine for 𝜋𝜋 − 𝑥𝑥, 𝜋𝜋 + 𝑥𝑥, and 2𝜋𝜋 − 𝑥𝑥 in terms of their
values for 𝑥𝑥, where 𝑥𝑥 is any real number.
Note: Does not include tangent.

CE96AF737F444757B3320C7E96ACA175.description:
Explain how the unit circle in the coordinate plane enables
the extension of trigonometric functions to all real numbers, interpreted
as radian measures of angles traversed counterclockwise around the unit
circle.

7F55E10F3C9B448CBCE01515D13725C1.description:
Understand the radian measure of an angle as the length of
the arc on the unit circle subtended by the angle.

DCE4E47443404328A2CF22DFCDDCA660.description: Extend the domain of trigonometric functions using the unit circle.

01219A8604A34D4FAE2D7C73F939CD60.description:
Interpret the parameters in a linear or exponential function
in terms of a context. (A1 and A2)

BEE219AB6C5649F09192F675BCF34990.description: Interpret expressions for functions in terms of the situation they model.

5D6D6B5930AA49868D91A81AFB0C5BB7.description:
For exponential models, express as a logarithm the solution
to 𝑎𝑎, 𝑏𝑏𝑐𝑐𝑐𝑐 = 𝑑𝑑 where 𝑎𝑎, 𝑏𝑏, 𝑐𝑐, and 𝑑𝑑 are numbers and the base 𝑎𝑎 is 2, 10, or
𝑒𝑒, evaluate the logarithm using technology.

08BE2680349340B9999F04F24CDF9CFC.description:
Construct linear and exponential functions, including
arithmetic and geometric sequences, given a graph, a description of a
relationship, or two input-output pairs (include reading these from a
table). (A1 and A2)

0D55A7FE98D04C948B9A790281091B62.description:
Construct and compare linear, quadratic, and exponential models and solve
problems.

52F0F7C84829488990845984442E2BC6.description:
Solve an equation of the form 𝑓𝑓(𝑥𝑥) = 𝑐𝑐 for a simple function 𝑓𝑓
that has an inverse and write an expression for the inverse. For
example,𝑓𝑓(𝑥𝑥) = 2𝑥𝑥3 or,𝑓𝑓(𝑥𝑥) = (𝑥𝑥+1)
(𝑥𝑥−1)
for 𝑥𝑥 ≠ 1.

3586C71B7EDA4180B12229C31B9EDAB6.description:
Identify the effect on linear and quadratic graphs of
replacing 𝑓𝑓(𝑥𝑥) by 𝑓𝑓(𝑥𝑥) + 𝑘𝑘 , 𝑘𝑘𝑘𝑘(𝑥𝑥), 𝑓𝑓(𝑘𝑘𝑘𝑘), and 𝑓𝑓(𝑥𝑥 + 𝑘𝑘) for specific values
of 𝑘𝑘 (both positive and negative); find the value of 𝑘𝑘 given the graphs.
Experiment with cases and illustrate an explanation of the effects on the
graph using technology. Include recognizing even and odd functions from
their graphs and algebraic expressions for them. (A1 and A2)

D8D0E505C9AA4307836AEDF1A3841A1C.description: Build new functions from existing functions.

35DF08EE6A764084BECF7EEDAD8CCB95.description:
Write arithmetic and geometric sequences both recursively
and with an explicit formula, use them to model situations, and translate
between the two forms. ★ (A1 and A2)

868E39DD9F3A4CC2AD9AD4FC2F358FA4.description:
Write a function that describes a relationship between two
quantities. Combine standard function types using arithmetic operations.
For example, build a function that models the temperature of a cooling
body by adding a constant function to a decaying exponential, and relate
these functions to the model. ★

40F719AD6E2345CEA85FF330C5D1CC5F.description: Build a function that models a relationship between two quantities.

83258D8DE9CC454FBD7EE8DFEE86948D.description:
Compare properties of two functions each represented in a
different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically in tables, or by
verbal descriptions). For example, given a graph of one quadratic
function and an algebraic expression for another, say which has the
larger maximum.

615433A5621D4CAE89BBEF03821BB6F7.description:
Write a function defined by an expression in different but
equivalent forms to reveal and explain different properties of the function.
For example, rewrite rational expressions to show the vertical
transformation. (A1 and A2)

D9C331DD293E43ADA35110FD839D7970.description: Note: a exists and can be found in A1.

B6905EDF6DFF43AF841D0593A45625E5.description:
Graph exponential and logarithmic functions, showing intercepts
and end behavior, and trigonometric functions, showing period,
midline, and amplitude.

784DEDC0A8E14D118A13877972978A9E.description:
Graph polynomial functions, identifying zeros when suitable
factorizations are available, and showing end behavior.

25BEB8208AC84AF3B1651D8080ACD01E.description:
Graph square root, cube root, and piecewise-defined functions,
including step functions and absolute value functions.

0C80F49A12E54B199766933EEEDBDB80.description:
Graph functions expressed symbolically and show key
features of the graph by hand in simple cases and using technology for
more complicated cases. ★ (A1 and A2)

2F63FA642B7347F49DD251186100009F.description:
Calculate and interpret the average rate of change of a
nonlinear function (presented symbolically or as a table) over a specified
interval. Estimate the rate of change from a graph. ★ (A1 and A2)

9657D025F9274C678AE30E0C9A609101.description:
Relate the domain of a function to its graph and, where
applicable, to the quantitative relationship it describes. For example, if the
function h(n) gives the number of person-hours it takes to assemble n
engines in a factory, then the positive integers would be an appropriate
domain for the function. ★ (A1 and A2)

C48D241947414FF489906678FD6038C2.description:
For a function that models a relationship between two
quantities, interpret key features of graphs and tables in terms of the
quantities, and sketch graphs showing key features given a verbal
description of the relationship. Key features may include intercepts;
intervals where the function is increasing, decreasing, positive, or
negative; maximum and minimum; and symmetries. ★ (A1 and A2)

9D75C003B90E4533AB2723BD879B7637.description: Interpret functions that arise in applications in terms of the context.

7D0B461190BC47BABE096E2A9EFE5112.description:
Graph and interpret (with the use of technology) the
solutions to a linear inequality in two variables as a half-plane (excluding
the boundary in the case of a strict inequality), and graph the solution set
to a system of linear inequalities in two variables as the intersection of
the corresponding half-planes. (A1 and A2)

FB6ADF55B8E04F1A86A8122BF1E76FE0.description:
Explain why the solution(s) of a system of equations are
the point(s) of intersection(s) on a coordinate plane. Find the solutions
approximately. For example, using technology to graph the functions,
make tables of values, or find successive approximations. Include cases
where 𝑓𝑓(𝑥𝑥) and/or 𝑔𝑔(𝑥𝑥) are quadratic, exponential, rational, absolute
value functions, polynomial, exponential, and logarithmic functions. ★ (A1
and A2)

E6105CCC985646739D4204A00B2C63E2.description:
Understand that the graph of an equation in two variables
is the set of all its solutions plotted in the coordinate plane, often forming
a curve (which could be a line). (A1 and A2)

8A527110D2ED429A993BB8BD72F56531.description: Represent and solve equations and inequalities graphically.

E75F128146CF45648D80A5F2B016CB93.description:
Solve a simple system consisting of a linear equation and
a quadratic equation in two variables algebraically and graphically. (A1
and A2)

5CD74B30BD464E99A6DB88217D636817.description: Solve quadratic equations with real solutions using any method.

D3EDEB95048E4D8FB9FDB9633D1E7683.description:
Use the method of completing the square to transform any
quadratic equation in 𝑥𝑥 into an equation of the form (𝑥𝑥 − 𝑝𝑝)2 = 𝑞𝑞
that has the same solutions.

CBCDDA3073A048158425163EF6790D42.description: Solve quadratic equations in one variable. (A1 and A2)

6011D5FBD4EF4CA7B5C291D4CE98EBAE.description: Solve equations and inequalities in one variable.

0624A24AC3AE4849A6EA6FB0407E3B5B.description:
Solve rational and radical equations in one variable and
give examples showing how extraneous solutions may arise. (A1 and A2)

5B030F48DCB3450796D3CFE7CA1C9B4D.description:
Explain each step in solving an equation as following from
the equality of numbers asserted at the previous step, starting from the
assumption that the original equation has a solution. Construct a viable
argument to justify a solution method. (A1 and A2)

286B2AE528B9454890BD3B7E7E7ADB76.description:
Understand solving equations as a process of reasoning and explain the
reasoning.

4518F9B248724E279AC58AF41DC10F1A.description:
Rearrange formulas to highlight a quantity of interest,
using the same reasoning as in solving equations. For example,
rearrange the formula for the area of a trapezoid, A =(b1 +b2)/2*h for the
length of one of the bases. (A1 and A2)

F63BDEBF34164235BBFAE8D74816242F.description:
Represent constraints by equations or inequalities, and by
systems of equations and/or inequalities, and interpret solutions as viable
or nonviable options in a modeling context. For example, represent
inequalities describing nutritional and cost constraints on combinations of
different foods. (A1 and A2)

9ED8B8FF98284AE2A1E6F508F7D9D288.description:
Create equations in two or more variables to represent
relationships between quantities; graph equations on coordinate axes
with labels and scales. (A1 and A2)

2ABE682D9741480FA6FE5C6D15740740.description:
Create equations and inequalities in one variable and use
them to solve problems. (A1 and A2)

7342D19611044B36B4053ACB3693AA22.description: Create equations that describe numbers or relationships.

E733CEFA4E8144DA95FCC9D918B40A71.description:
Rewrite simple rational expressions in different forms;
write 𝑎𝑎(𝑥𝑥)
𝑏𝑏(𝑥𝑥)
in the form 𝑞𝑞(𝑥𝑥) + 𝑟𝑟(𝑥𝑥)
𝑏𝑏(𝑥𝑥)
, where 𝑎𝑎(𝑥𝑥), 𝑏𝑏(𝑥𝑥), 𝑞𝑞(𝑥𝑥), and 𝑟𝑟(𝑥𝑥) are
polynomials with the degree of r(x) less than the degree of b(x). For
example, in the same way one may view 11
7 as (7+4)
7 = 1 + 4
7
, one can view
(𝑥𝑥+7)
(𝑥𝑥+3)
as ((𝑥𝑥+3)+4)
(𝑥𝑥+3) = 1 + 4
𝑥𝑥+3

388889C86994477FBC57215C3E3EF321.description:
Identify zeros of polynomials when suitable factorizations
are available and use the zeros to construct a rough graph of the function
defined by the polynomial.

985AF708D19B4A1F9B22AE936EF7DDBF.description:
Know and apply the Remainder Theorem: For a
polynomial p(x) and a number a, the remainder on division by 𝑥𝑥 – 𝑎𝑎 is
𝑝𝑝(𝑎𝑎), so 𝑝𝑝(𝑎𝑎) = 0 if and only if (𝑥𝑥 − 𝑎𝑎) is a factor of 𝑝𝑝(𝑥𝑥).

6329D07DD46745249402FF4CC863E840.description: Understand the relationship between zeros and factors of polynomials.

6B3DAC9DA8BF4550840997C1DE749416.description:
Understand that polynomials form a system analogous to
the integers, namely, they are closed under the operations of addition,
subtraction, and multiplication; add, subtract, and multiply polynomials.

1FDD26F5CC824B98B0A9F874277E9A1A.description: Arithmetic with Polynomials and Rational Expressions

622C55D5F9D140888950722D32EDB8A3.description:
Apply the formula for the sum of a finite geometric series
(when the common ratio is not 1), and use the formula to solve problems.
For example, calculate mortgage payments. ★

45C817A44AFB4656A0831268919EB256.description:
Use the properties of exponents to transform expressions for
exponential functions. For example, the expression 3𝑥𝑥 can be
rewritten as (1 + 2)𝑥𝑥 to reveal the growth rate is 200%. ★

BE240D32072D4BC39457C42B6835356F.description:
Complete the square in a quadratic equation to reveal the
maximum or minimum value of the function it defines.

57255B8F77B74D86A4FA8A234ADDCE95.description:
Factor a quadratic expression to reveal the zeros of the function
it defines.

F783F0370AFA457E83D3BEEFD441D8A9.description:
Choose and produce an equivalent form of an expression
or equation to reveal and explain properties of the quantity represented
by the expression. (A1 and A2)

D1CAD702628B46679481D6DDD0C06F73.description: Write expressions and equations in equivalent forms to solve problems.

C936E472D1E5412E8257720DFF2D0989.description:
Use the structure of an expression to identify ways to
rewrite it. For example, see 𝑥𝑥4 − 𝑦𝑦4 as (𝑥𝑥2)2 – (𝑦𝑦2)2, thus recognizing it
as a difference of squares that can be factored as (𝑥𝑥2 – 𝑦𝑦2)(𝑥𝑥2 + 𝑦𝑦2).

8BED1BB1B40240D9B5FF607E05081038.description:
Interpret expressions that represent a quantity in terms
of its context. For example, interpret 𝑃𝑃(1 + 𝑟𝑟)𝑛𝑛 as the product of 𝑃𝑃 and 𝑎𝑎
factor not depending on 𝑃𝑃. ★

D611C10833B540669475833ABEE0C838.description: Seeing Structure in Expressions and Equations

3A5C377028EC41AA9D5674E64A37C848.description:
Solve quadratic equations with real coefficients that have
complex solutions.

49D9231E95FD4BE4981C13350A57E921.description: Use complex numbers in polynomial identities and equations.

D513516EADD0436CBC6FF41269817D28.description:
Use the relation 𝑖𝑖
2 = −1and the commutative, associative,
and distributive properties to add, subtract, and multiply complex
numbers.

A34A8862B95B482DB23CB3BE6996678B.description:
Know there is a complex number 𝑖𝑖 such that 𝑖𝑖2 = −1, and
every complex number has the form 𝑎𝑎 + 𝑏𝑏𝑏𝑏 with 𝑎𝑎 and 𝑏𝑏 real.

9E678E4108524F3D9A4FB9AF0EC50040.description: Perform arithmetic operations with complex numbers.

121D39C5940A41C3A6580CE5CC0C2A26.description:
Choose a level of accuracy appropriate to limitations on
measurement when reporting quantities.

A9A08BB89F004C568BCBA6D2B5935DC7.description:
Define appropriate quantities for the purpose of descriptive
modeling.

8833D51AFE954625BE21BBC908AE71FC.description:
Use units to understand problems and to guide the solution
of multi-step problems; choose and interpret units consistently in
formulas; choose and interpret the scale and the origin in graphs and
data displays. (A1 and A2)

6D82C311339346BAB1BEE704AFD5526E.description: Reason quantitatively and use units to solve problems.

4BC680E3E25F42D5A74288AC6B70B403.description:
Rewrite expressions involving radicals and rational
exponents using the properties of exponents.

3C293E32BFB647AE969873C9D3E48D64.description:
Explain how the definition of the meaning of rational
exponents follows from extending the properties of integer exponents to
those values, allowing for a notation for radicals in terms of rational
exponents. For example, we define 5
1
3 to be the cube root of 5 because
we want (51
3)3 = 5(
1
3)
3
to hold, so 5(
1
3)
3
must equal 5.

A3629FE7EA1D4B6DAF69FF3B80C0D1CE.description: Extend the properties of exponents to rational exponents.
